Furthermore, they must enhance scientific backing and surveillance for the 2030 Agenda by heightening awareness of relevant national indicators of sustainability and integrating these indicators closely with the objectives of the agenda. By doing so, they will create a strong foundation for their national sustainable development endeavors based on the 2030 Agenda.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are Finland's key actions to promote sustainable development and independent advocacy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland requires a single, visually clear indicator system to serve as a comprehensive focus for discussions, functioning as an independent high-level advocate for sustainable development with the mandate to comment on critical governmental plans affecting it. Additionally, Finland aims to make sustainable development a permanent cross-administrative component of foreign and development policy, and has a viable plan to increase development aid funding to 0.7% of its Gross National Income (GNI), while securing a broad-based commitment to fulfill this pledge.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland intend to strengthen its role in promoting sustainable development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: To strengthen its role in promoting sustainable development, Finland plans to establish a single, visually clear indicator system serving as a comprehensive focus for discussions, which will operate independently as a high-level advocate for sustainable development. The system will be granted the mandate to comment on the most significant governmental plans impacting sustainable development. Furthermore, Finland intends to make sustainable development a permanent cross-administrative aspect of its foreign and development policy. To achieve this, Finland has devised a practical strategy to raise development aid funding to 0.7% of its Gross National Income (GNI) and secure a broad-based commitment to meet this pledge.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland incorporate the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into its national planning, budgeting, and reporting processes?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland requires all line ministries to compile their policies and measures on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda into the Government's Annual Report to the Parliament on a yearly basis. The incorporation of the SDGs into Finnish planning, budgeting, and reporting processes varies in success. Additionally, Finland's sustainable development policy aims to reduce inequality and strengthen the evaluation of human rights impact in all foreign policy matters. This aligns with the "Leave No One Behind" principle of the SDGs. (Source: Context provided)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps does Finland take annually to report on the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in its government policies and budgets?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: All line ministries in Finland are required to compile their policies and measures on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda into the Government's Annual Report to the Parliament on a yearly basis. This process allows for the tracking and reporting of progress towards achieving the SDGs within Finnish governance structures. (Source: Context provided)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role have the Government Annual Reports played in disseminating information about Finland's progress towards the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Government Annual Reports have acted as essential sources of information, summarizing Finland's annual policies and measures related to the 2030 Agenda. They have provided updates on key areas, actions, and actors involved in sustainable development efforts. Since 2017, these reports have been published regularly, with a total of four reports released in 2017, 2018, 2019, and 2020.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How have Government Annual Reports contributed to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, and what is required of them moving forward?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Government Annual Reports have played a significant role in mainstreaming the implementation of the 2030 Agenda by providing valuable tools for officials, supporting sustainable development coordinators in line Ministries, and facilitating dialogue between different stakeholders. Moving forward, in addition to their existing functions, they are also required to include essential information for the promotion and monitoring of sustainable development in their yearly budget planning and follow-up indicators. This will help strengthen the overall implementation process.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What impact have Government Annual Reports had on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, and what new responsibilities have been assigned to them?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Government Annual Reports have been instrumental in supporting the implementation of the 2030 Agenda by providing valuable resources for officials, legitimizing the work of sustainable development coordinators, and fostering dialogue among various stakeholders. In addition to their previous roles, they are now mandated to incorporate crucial information related to sustainable development into their annual budget planning and follow-up indicators. This expansion of responsibilities aims to enhance the effectiveness of the implementation process.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has Finland incorporated sustainable development into its budget proposals in recent years?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has been gradually improving the transparency of sustainable development in its budget proposals by incorporating sustainable development as an integral part of the drafting process. The 2018 budget proposal was the first time that each administrative branch included language on sustainable development in the proposal. However, addressing trade-offs and synergies related to sustainable development remains challenging due to politically sensitive issues and deep-rooted ideological differences, which are typically addressed at the ministerial level.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps has Finland taken to address trade-offs and synergies related to sustainable development in its budget proposals?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: While several procedures exist for identifying trade-offs and synergies related to sustainable development, these issues are often difficult to reconcile due to their politically sensitive nature and deep-rooted ideological differences. As a result, many conflicts are addressed at the political (ministerial) level. In recent years, Finland has aimed to improve the transparency of sustainable development in its budget proposals by incorporating sustainable development as an integral part of the drafting process. This includes having each administrative branch include language on sustainable development in the budget proposal for the first time in 2018. However, addressing the underlying conflicts and finding solutions remains a challenge.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How did the administrative branches approach sustainable development in the 2019 budget proposal, and what was new about this approach?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The administrative branches discussed measures related to sustainable development in their contributions to the 2019 budget proposal, covering all of the UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). A notable change was the addition of a new chapter entitled 'Sustainable development' in the General Strategy and section. This new chapter took a more holistic view on sustainable development, particularly focusing on the SDGs relevant to carbon neutrality. This shift represented an extension of sustainable development budgeting beyond a sectoral perspective.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What was unique about the approach to sustainable development in the 2019 budget proposal?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: In the 2019 budget proposal, there was a significant expansion of sustainable development budgeting. This was demonstrated through the inclusion of a new chapter titled 'Sustainable development' in the General Strategy and section. This chapter adopted a more comprehensive perspective on sustainable development, emphasizing the importance of the SDGs related to carbon neutrality. By taking a more holistic view, the budget proposal went beyond the traditional sectoral focus and offered a more integrated approach to sustainable development.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Which aspects of the 2020 budget proposal are dedicated to advancing Finland's carbon neutrality goals, and what specific appropriations does it identify for this purpose?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The budget proposal's chapter on sustainable development identifies several appropriations aimed at promoting biodiversity, enhancing the wellbeing of nature and the environment, reducing emissions, advancing bioeconomy solutions, and developing Finland towards a low-carbon society. Additionally, the chapter examines the relevant taxes in the budget proposal that contribute to the carbon neutrality target.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are some of the ways the 2020 budget proposal intends to support Finland's transition to a low-carbon society, and how does it plan to achieve carbon neutrality through specific appropriations?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The 2020 budget proposal includes various appropriations designed to promote Finland's transition to a low-carbon society. These include investments in biodiversity, environmental wellbeing, reducing emissions, advancing bioeconomy solutions, and promoting sustainable development. Specifically, the identified appropriations aim to address aspects such as renewable energy, circular economy, and green transportation. Furthermore, the chapter in the budget proposal examines the relevance of certain taxes to the carbon neutrality target.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What types of taxes and subsidies does the budget proposal address in relation to carbon neutrality?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The budget proposal discusses various taxes such as energy taxes, vehicle tax, car tax, waste tax, and excise duty on certain beverage containers. Additionally, it addresses environmentally harmful subsidies that increase the utilization of natural resources and the environmental burden in the subsidized enterprise or sector, despite being introduced for non-environmental reasons.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Which subsidies does the budget proposal identify as environmentally harmful?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The budget proposal identifies subsidies that result in an increase in the utilization of natural resources and the environmental burden in the subsidized enterprise or sector as environmentally harmful subsidies. These subsidies are introduced based on non-environmental considerations.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What is the rationale behind the introduction of environmentally harmful subsidies mentioned in the budget proposal?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The rationale for the introduction of environmentally harmful subsidies mentioned in the budget proposal is based on non-environmental considerations.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland's government approach sustainable development budgeting, particularly regarding the phasing out of environmentally harmful subsidies?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's government is committed to continuing sustainable development budgeting, which includes considering measures to phase out environmentally harmful subsidies. However, they are taking a gradual approach, increasing information and experimenting with different models to determine the best approach for Finland. Previous studies from Finland have shown that these subsidies can have positive impacts on local livelihoods and income opportunities. Therefore, the government is carefully assessing the potential consequences before making any significant changes.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps is Finland's government taking towards sustainable development budgeting, specifically concerning the elimination of environmentally harmful subsidies?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's government is committed to implementing sustainable development budgeting, which involves continuing the practice while evaluating methods for phasing out environmentally harmful subsidies. They are taking a gradual approach, providing more information and testing various models to identify the optimal solution for Finland. Prior research indicates that these subsidies can contribute positively to local economies and livelihoods. Consequently, the government is cautiously examining the potential repercussions before making definitive decisions.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has the gradual approach to sustainable development budgeting benefited the budget review process despite its early stage?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The gradual approach to sustainable development budgeting has allowed for the review process to be conducted with limited administrative resources. It has also raised awareness about sustainable development issues, increased the transparency of budget proposals, and helped outline the appropriations included in the proposals as a whole. This initiative has been spearheaded by the Ministry of Environment and Agriculture in collaboration with other ministries.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are the advantages of the gradual approach to sustainable development budgeting according to the provided context?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The advantages of the gradual approach to sustainable development budgeting include allowing for the review process to be conducted with limited administrative resources, raising awareness about sustainable development issues, increasing the transparency of budget proposals, and helping outline the appropriations included in the proposals as a whole. This approach has been led by the Ministry of Environment and Agriculture in partnership with other ministries.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has the Finnish government approached the integration of sustainable development goals (SDGs) into its ministries' strategies and programs?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Finnish government has initiated the process of incorporating the SDGs into sectoral policies and strategies of line ministries. This includes integrating the goals into guidance and performance agreements with governmental institutes and offices. Additionally, there has been cooperation between budget drafters and sustainable development experts, as well as consultation with stakeholders, including civil society actors, during the development process. The early stages of this implementation were favorably positioned towards sustainable development budgeting. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8, Report on the Implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role have budget drafters and sustainable development experts played in the Finnish government's approach to implementing the SDGs?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Budget drafters and sustainable development experts have collaborated in the Finnish government's efforts to implement the SDGs. They have worked together during the development process, which has included a favorable stance towards sustainable development budgeting. Additionally, there was a broader consultation with stakeholders, including civil society actors, during the early stages of the development process. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8, Report on the Implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How have Ministries addressed internal coordination for sustainable development, and what are the current challenges regarding the implementation of this agenda?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Ministries have established or fortified internal coordination networks aimed at promoting sustainable development. These networks serve to highlight sustainable development issues to various Ministry departments and units. However, there exists significant variation among Ministries concerning the role and standing of 2030 Agenda coordinators and their respective networks. Although sustainable development has gained traction in Ministries' strategies and operations, the Auditors' Report indicates that a comprehensive evaluation of policies from an ecological, economic, and social sustainability perspective remains absent.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What measures have Ministries taken to promote internal coordination for sustainable development, and what obstacles persist in implementing this agenda?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: To foster internal coordination for sustainable development, Ministries have set up or reinforced dedicated networks. Their purpose is to bring attention to sustainable development matters within different Ministry departments and units. Despite the growing significance of sustainable development in Ministries' plans and activities, the Auditors' Report reveals that a thorough analysis of policies based on ecological, economic, and social sustainability criteria is yet to be carried out. Additionally, there are notable discrepancies among Ministries regarding the positioning of 2030 Agenda coordinators and their coordination networks.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How have sustainable development principles been incorporated into the work of Ministries in the study, and what is the frequency of mentions in their performance management documents?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The implementation of sustainable development principles in the 11 Ministries under study has primarily involved adopting SDG objectives as their own goals. However, there is a lack of clear and coordinated connection between sustainable development and the content of policy preparation within these Ministries. Sustainable development was mentioned infrequently in the performance management documents, and only occasional references were found. Therefore, while some progress has been made towards integrating sustainable development into Ministry work, more comprehensive and systematic approaches are needed to effectively align policies with sustainable development goals.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What specific actions have the Ministries taken to incorporate sustainable development into their work, and how often is this mentioned in their performance management documents?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Ministries in the study have mainly adopted SDG objectives as their own goals in order to incorporate sustainable development into their work. However, there is a noticeable absence of a clear and coordinated approach to connecting sustainable development with the content of policy preparation at an individual Ministry level. In the performance management documents reviewed, sustainable development was only mentioned occasionally and infrequently. Thus, although some steps have been taken towards integrating sustainable development into Ministry work, further efforts are required to create a more comprehensive and systematic approach for aligning policies with sustainable development goals.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has the National Commission on Sustainable Development contributed to the incorporation of the SDGs into Finland's national strategy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The National Commission on Sustainable Development has been instrumental in designing, preparing, and compiling Finland's national strategy on sustainable development since 2006. One such reference was found in the performance agreement template of this commission, where units subject to steering were asked to define themselves how their activities supported the implementation of the SDGs. This demonstrates the importance of the commission in integrating the SDGs into Finland's national strategy.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role did the National Commission on Sustainable Development play in creating Finland's first national strategy on sustainable development, and how have they continued to support the integration of the SDGs into subsequent strategies?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The National Commission on Sustainable Development played a significant role in creating Finland's first national strategy on sustainable development back in 2006. Since then, they have continued to contribute to the process by incorporating the SDGs into their performance agreement templates, asking units subject to steering to define how their activities support the implementation of these goals. This approach highlights the commission's ongoing commitment to promoting sustainable development in Finland.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role did Finland's "Commitment to Sustainable Development - The Finland we want by 2050" play in the country's approach to the United Nations' 2030 Agenda?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Adopted in 2014, Finland's long-term sustainability strategy served as the foundation for the Government's first Implementation Plan for the 2030 Agenda in 2017. In 2016, the strategy was updated to align with the UN's agenda, and it continues to provide a common vision for Finnish society as a whole: "A prosperous Finland with global responsibility for sustainability and the carrying capacity of nature." The strategy represents the views of various societal actors and guides the implementation of sustainable development initiatives across administrative sectors. Additionally, the strategy's key objectives and principles were updated to align with the 2030 Agenda.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How did the adoption of the EU Sustainability and Smart Growth Strategy contribute to building coherence and trust between the Finnish government and society regarding the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The adoption of the EU Sustainability and Smart Growth Strategy enabled the Finnish government to build coherence and trust between itself and the broader society on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. This was achieved through the correspondence between the national objectives and the sustainable development goals (SDGs) of the 2030 Agenda, reflecting the commitment of Finnish society towards sustainable development. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8, Figure 5.)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: In what way did the EU Sustainability and Smart Growth Strategy facilitate the alignment of Finnish national objectives with the SDGs of the 2030 Agenda?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The EU Sustainability and Smart Growth Strategy played a crucial role in facilitating the alignment of Finnish national objectives with the SDGs of the 2030 Agenda. By fostering a strong societal commitment towards sustainable development, the strategy encouraged the Finnish government to adopt policies and initiatives that corresponded with the global goals outlined in the 2030 Agenda. As a result, the Finnish national objectives became more closely aligned with the SDGs, enabling greater coherence and trust between the government and society during the implementation process. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8, Figure 5.)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What did the publications from the Prime Minister's Office (2020:8) and the independent assessment (POLKU, 2019) reveal about the effectiveness of Finland's Society's Commitment in guiding Ministry work towards sustainable development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The publications from the Prime Minister's Office (2020:8) and the independent assessment (POLKU, 2019) discovered that Finland's Society's Commitment had not adequately influenced Ministry work in terms of promoting equal prospects for well-being, a participatory society for all, working sustainably, building a sustainable society and local communities, creating a carbon-neutral society, fostering a resource-wise economy, adopting lifestyles respectful of nature's carrying capacity, and making decision-making respectful of nature. Despite these findings, both sources emphasized the importance of continuing efforts to advance sustainable development in Finland.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does the incorporation of the 2030 Agenda into Policy S's RDI roadmap contribute to sustainable growth and wellbeing?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The integration of the 2030 Agenda into Policy S's RDI strategy facilitates sustainable growth and wellbeing through high-level knowledge, research, and innovation. This approach allows Policy S to align its development efforts with global sustainable development goals while maintaining its own national strategy, which is expected to be updated during the new term 2020-2023. Despite some confusion among stakeholders due to having two policy frameworks, the attractiveness and comprehensiveness of the 2030 Agenda have made it more appealing for communication purposes. Larger companies have already adopted the framework, but it remains uncertain what the future holds for Policy S's Society Commitment. Ultimately, this alignment will help Policy S contribute to sustainable development on both local and global scales.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does the roadmap prioritize research and innovation in addressing global development challenges and the impact of the pandemic?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The roadmap emphasizes the significance of research and innovation in generating solutions to the global development challenges outlined in the 2030 Agenda. It plans to achieve this through developing the knowledge base, boosting RDI cooperation among research organizations, businesses, and the third sector, and promoting innovativeness within the public sector. Additionally, efforts have been made to integrate SDGs into research and innovation policies, instruments, and activities. These initiatives aim to not only tackle development challenges but also help mitigate the societal effects of the pandemic.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What specific actions is the roadmap taking to incorporate the SDGs into research and innovation policies?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The roadmap has taken several concrete steps to integrate the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into research and innovation policies, instruments, and activities. This includes developing the knowledge base, fostering collaboration between research organizations, businesses, and the third sector, and promoting innovativeness within the public sector. These actions aim to address both global development challenges and the impact of the pandemic on society.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Which organizations are the main public funders for research and innovation, and how are they integrating Circular Economy into their programs?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The European Commission (EC) and Horizon Europe, as well as Eureka and Eurostars under the European Innovation Council and SMEs Executive Agency, are the main public funding organizations for research and innovation. They have integrated Circular Economy into their programs to address various challenges, including clean energy, renewable raw materials, the circular economy, health, and digitalization. EC's Horizon Europe enhances the achievement of sustainability goals through annual open calls and funding for cutting-edge research. Higher education institutions and public research institutions are also focusing on sustainable development as part of their strategies and areas of research. Additionally, Eureka and Eurostars offer programs to scale up innovations for international markets. (Figure 6) and (of ) relate to these themes.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How do the European Commission (EC), Horizon Europe, Eureka, and Eurostars support sustainable development and scaling up of innovations?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The European Commission (EC) and its research and innovation funding program Horizon Europe provide annual open calls and funding for cutting-edge research focused on sustainable development themes like clean energy, renewable raw materials, the circular economy, health, and digitalization. Higher education institutions and public research institutions are incorporating sustainable development into their strategies and research. Eureka and Eurostars, under the European Innovation Council and SMEs Executive Agency, support the scaling up of innovations for international markets through their programs. These initiatives cover themes such as clean energy, renewable raw materials, the circular economy, health, and digitalization. (Figure 6) and (of ) represent the specific programs related to these themes.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How did Finland contribute to sustainable development through inter-disciplinary and transdisciplinary research and education in 2018?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland established HELSUS in 2018 to promote sustainable transformation through inter-disciplinary and transdisciplinary research and education.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development impacted various programs in Finland?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The 2030 Agenda has been integrated into various Finnish programs, opening new business opportunities and accelerating solutions to sustainable development challenges. Promising markets include health and wellbeing, smart and clean energy, smart industry, sustainable communities, circular economy, personalized health, smart energy batteries, circular food, and Finland's developing markets. Additionally, Finland promotes cooperation and coherence between research, innovation, and development policies. Specific initiatives include AI Business, Digital Trust, New Space Economy, Game changers Entertainment, and Talent Finland.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finnish innovation policy support various industries in their transition towards sustainable growth, and what role does EU funding play in this process?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finnish innovation policy provides support to industries including mining, tourism, space, industrial, and health sectors, in their transition towards sustainable growth. The financing of Research, Development, and Innovation (RDI) activities focused on solving sustainability challenges is achieved through EU funding.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What is the objective of Finland's 2019 strategy titled "Championing education and culture with knowledge, skills and feeling," and how does the Ministry of Education and Culture's April 2020 policy fit into this goal?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The main objective of Finland's 2019 strategy is to strengthen sustainable development, sustainable growth, and vitality in Finland. The Ministry of Education and Culture's April 2020 policy, titled "Finland's Cultural and Educational Policy and its Administrative Branch," aligns with this goal by supporting the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. The rationale behind this is that achieving the goals of the 2030 Agenda requires strong support from education, research, cultural, youth, and sport policies. Therefore, the Ministry's policy aims to contribute to Finland's sustainable future by focusing on these areas.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does the Ministry of Education and Culture's April 2020 policy support Finland's 2030 Agenda goals?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Ministry of Education and Culture's April 2020 policy supports Finland's 2030 Agenda goals by providing strong support for education, research, cultural, youth, and sport policies. This alignment is based on the understanding that achieving the goals of the 2030 Agenda necessitates robust backing from these sectors. Consequently, the Ministry's policy contributes to Finland's sustainable future by focusing on these areas.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What is Finland's current administration's focus in promoting comprehensive sustainable development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's current administration is promoting comprehensive sustainable development by consolidating and maintaining equal rights to cultural engagement, providing high standards of early childhood education and care, ensuring a high level of education, offering up-to-date skills, encouraging continuous learning, and making information accessible. The administration's approach is based on an economically, ecologically, and socially sustainable society built on competence and inclusion. (2019-)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland's current administration aim to achieve a shift towards sustainable development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's current administration aims to achieve a shift towards sustainable development by fostering a cultural change that values equal rights to cultural engagement, high-quality early childhood education and care, a high level of education, up-to-date skills, continuous learning, and accessibility of information. This approach is grounded in creating an economically, ecologically, and socially sustainable society based on competence and inclusion. (2019-)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are the objectives of Finland's Programme for promoting competence, education, culture, and innovation?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The objectives include raising the level of education and competence among the population at all levels, reducing disparities in learning outcomes, and promoting educational equality.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland prioritize education and training to promote wellbeing, gender equality, and international attractiveness?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland focuses on developing education and training at all levels, placing emphasis on increasing wellbeing and community spirit through a competence approach that includes learning and problem-solving skills, multiliteracy, and creative and critical thinking. The future aims for everyone to have the capacity for lifelong and continuous learning, including in the workplace, to enhance gender equality and non-discrimination in society and make Finland an internationally attractive place to study, conduct research, and invest. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are Finland's goals regarding education and training as outlined in their implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's priorities in education and training include promoting wellbeing and community spirit, enhancing gender equality and non-discrimination, and making Finland an internationally attractive place for studying, conducting research, and investing. This is achieved through a competence-based approach to learning and problem-solving skills, multiliteracy, and creative and critical thinking, as well as encouraging lifelong and continuous learning opportunities in the workplace. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does continuous learning development in the Finnish context focus on sustainable development beyond just learning contents?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: In addition to improving learning contents, Finland's continuous learning development approach aims to enhance learning environments, everyday organizational culture, and school management and leadership to promote sustainable development effectively captured in documents like the National Core Curricula for early childhood education and care, basic education, and vocational education and training. This holistic approach ensures that all aspects of education contribute to sustainable development.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are the key areas targeted for improvement in Finland's continuous learning development strategy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Finnish continuous learning development strategy focuses on enhancing learning environments, everyday organizational culture, and school management and leadership, alongside improving learning contents, to promote sustainable development effectively. These improvements are already well-established in learning content documents such as the National Core Curricula for early childhood education and care, basic education, and vocational education and training.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How do universities and universities of applied sciences in Finland contribute to the country's competitiveness, wellbeing, education, culture, and sustainable development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Universities and universities of applied sciences in Finland play a significant role in promoting Finnish competitiveness, wellbeing, all-round education, culture, and sustainable development through their operations. As autonomous entities, they are responsible for their own administration, research, and teaching. Some institutions have made efforts to integrate sustainable development into various fields of study.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps have certain higher education institutions taken towards incorporating sustainable development into their academic programs?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Several higher education institutions in Finland have systematically worked to integrate sustainable development into different fields of study as part of their operations. This reflects their commitment to promoting sustainability and contributing to the country's overall goals.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: In what ways do universities and universities of applied sciences in Finland operate independently?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Universities and universities of applied sciences in Finland function as autonomous entities, managing their own administration, research, and teaching. This independence allows them to tailor their approaches to best serve the needs of their students and contribute to the broader societal objectives of the country.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What is the role of Finnish higher education institutions in teacher education and sustainable development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finnish higher education institutions play a significant role in teacher education and sustainable development. They offer transdisciplinary minor subject modules in sustainable development to create solutions to the challenges presented by sustainable development and equip students with the necessary competence capital required on the labor market. Additionally, the Finnish Ministry of Education and Culture established a Teacher Education Forum in 2016 to draft national guidelines for developing teacher education. Teachers are highly valued professionals in Finland, and this initiative aims to enhance their education and prepare them for the evolving demands of the workforce. The focus on sustainability reflects the growing importance of environmental issues in education and society as a whole. By offering specialized training in this area, Finnish universities contribute to the development of future teachers who can effectively address these concerns in their classrooms and beyond. Overall, the integration of sustainable development into teacher education represents an innovative approach to preparing educators for the complexities of modern teaching and learning environments.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has Finland prioritized education policies in recent years, focusing on both teachers' development and students' flexible learning pathways?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: In recent years, Finland's education policy has placed emphasis on cooperation between teachers, with a focus on their digital skills and innovative teaching methods through a network of teacher tutors. Simultaneously, there has been a priority given to students' flexible learning pathways based on a 'leave no-one behind' approach, ensuring an education system without progress-hindering dead ends from early childhood education and care through to higher education.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are the key aspects of Finland's current education policy regarding teachers' development and students' learning pathways?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's education policy currently focuses on promoting cooperation between teachers, enhancing their digital skills and innovative teaching methods through a network of teacher tutors. Additionally, it emphasizes students' flexible learning pathways based on a 'leave no-one behind' approach, creating an education system free from progress-hindering dead ends for children from early childhood education and care to higher education.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How have the Finnish authorities been working to facilitate flexible learning pathways between vocational programs and higher education?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Finnish government has implemented several initiatives to enable students to transition smoothly between vocational programs and higher education. Notable among these efforts are the reform of vocational education and training and the enactment of the new Jobs and Training Act (531/2017), which took effect at the start of 2018. These changes aim to maximize recognition of prior learning, expand diverse pathways to higher education, enhance pass rates, and establish a framework for continuous learning. Specifically, the reform of vocational education and training focuses on improving the quality and relevance of vocational education, while the Jobs and Training Act introduces more flexible study paths and financing arrangements. Together, these measures seek to create a more adaptive and inclusive educational system that caters to the evolving needs of students and the labor market.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does the new vocational education and training system allow students to apply and complete their studies flexibly?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The new system offers a rolling application procedure, allowing students to apply when necessary. Students are given personal study plans and can complete entire vocational qualifications or individual modules according to their needs. Preparatory education and competence development programmes are also available. Assessment of competence is based on meeting the qualification requirements for vocational skills and competencies, regardless of where, when, or how they were acquired.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What advantages does the new vocational education and training system provide in terms of flexibility and assessment?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The new system provides students with the ability to apply for vocational education and training at any time using a rolling application procedure. They are given personalized study plans and can choose to complete entire qualifications or individual modules based on their needs. Additionally, competence is assessed solely based on meeting the qualification requirements for vocational skills and competencies, regardless of where, when, or how they were acquired.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How is competence demonstrated in Finland's education system, and what reforms are being implemented to digitalize education?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Competence, including sustainable development skills, is demonstrated through practical work tasks in real-life work situations. The Finnish education system is undergoing reforms to digitalize education, which includes increasing modularity in higher education, providing digital course offerings and guidance counseling services, and modernizing pedagogical methods. These changes aim to improve accessibility and boost international student recruitment. Additionally, the contributions of liberal adult education institutions such as folk high schools, adult education centers, study centers, sports institutes, and summer universities remain significant in Finland.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps is Finland taking to digitalize its education system and why?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: In order to enhance accessibility, expand international student recruitment, and modernize educational methods, Finland is implementing reforms to digitalize its education system. This involves increasing the modularity of higher education, offering more digital courses and fully digital degree programs, and upgrading guidance counseling services. The goal is to make education more accessible and attractive to students from around the world. Furthermore, the country recognizes the importance of continuing education and values the contributions of liberal adult education institutions like folk high schools, adult education centers, study centers, sports institutes, and summer universities.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are some challenges that require special attention in promoting sustainable development in Finland, according to recent reports?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The challenges include increasing social exclusion, combatting climate change, deteriorating environmental status, and unsustainable consumer habits. Additionally, there is a concern that the level of education among young people is no longer rising. These issues call for themes related to educational responsibility and quality improvement. Various Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) operating in educational, cultural, youth, sports, and physical activity sectors contribute to addressing these challenges by producing learning materials and providing training in sustainable development issues within and outside schools and liberal adult education institutions. The promotion of lifelong learning based on the principles of personal development, sustainable development, social coherence, equality, and active citizenship plays a crucial role in overcoming these challenges.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How do Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) contribute to promoting sustainable development in Finland?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) operating in educational, cultural, youth, sports, and physical activity sectors significantly contribute to promoting sustainable development in Finland by producing learning materials and providing training in sustainable development issues both within schools and liberal adult education institutions and outside as part of their core activities. Their efforts aim to address challenges such as increasing social exclusion, combatting climate change, deteriorating environmental status, and unsustainable consumer habits through educational responsibility and quality improvement.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What percentage of young people lack an upper secondary certificate each year, and what are the potential consequences?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Approximately 15% of young people do not obtain an upper secondary certificate after completing comprehensive school. This lack of certification increases the risk of social exclusion and hinders their ability to pursue further studies or find employment. Additionally, it contributes to growing learning differences between genders and regions.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How many young people annually fail to acquire an upper secondary certificate, and what are the possible outcomes?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: One out of every nine young people (approximately 15%) does not receive an upper secondary certificate upon finishing comprehensive school. Consequently, they face an increased likelihood of social exclusion and may struggle to continue their education or secure employment. Furthermore, this trend exacerbates existing learning disparities among genders and geographical locations.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What is the annual statistic for young people who don't have an upper secondary certificate, and what are the associated risks?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Around 15% of young people do not earn an upper secondary certificate following their time in comprehensive school. As a result, they encounter heightened risks of social exclusion and difficulty accessing higher education or suitable employment opportunities. Moreover, these issues contribute to widening learning gaps between various demographic groups and territories.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How are the education and training provisions for second-generation immigrants being addressed in this context, and what specific measures have been implemented?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: In response to lower learning outcomes among second-generation immigrants compared to the mainstream population, the focus is on the flexibility of education and training. Measures include increasing wellbeing and community spirit. Education and training providers have received discretionary government grants, which were expanded in 2019 to cover early childhood education and care. These grants enable the hiring of extra teachers and classroom assistants to decrease teaching group sizes in schools requiring additional support. This approach aims to improve educational opportunities for second-generation immigrants.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps have been taken to enhance the education and training experience for second-generation immigrants in this setting?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: To address the issue of lower learning outcomes among second-generation immigrants, the emphasis is on providing flexible education and training options. Efforts are underway to boost wellbeing and foster community spirit. Government grants have been extended to cover early childhood education and care, allowing education and training providers to hire more teachers and classroom assistants. By reducing teaching group sizes in schools needing extra assistance, these initiatives aim to create better learning environments for second-generation immigrants.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What efforts are being made in Finland to encourage boys to take up reading for pleasure, and what are the educational goals for the country?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Special efforts are being made to encourage boys to take up reading for pleasure. In terms of education, Finland aims to increase the percentage of adults aged 25-34 who have completed a higher education degree from the current 41% to 50% by 2030. This goal is in line with targets set by the European Union and other OECD countries. Additionally, Finland has a high participation rate in adult education, with over half of all adults engaging in such programs.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland's higher education attainment rate compare internationally, and what steps is the country taking to improve it?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's higher education attainment rate among adults aged 25-34 is currently around the average and below some other countries' rates. To address this, Finland has set a target to increase the percentage of adults in this age group who have completed a higher education degree to 50% by 2030. This goal is in line with targets set by the European Union and other OECD countries. The country also has a high participation rate in adult education.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Why does participation in adult education vary among individuals based on their educational attainment level, labour-market position, and socio-economic status?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Individuals with higher educational attainment levels, better labour-market positions, and superior socio-economic status are more likely to participate in adult education.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How have efforts been made to prevent bullying, harassment, and hate speech in education and training, especially in nonformal learning contexts?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Prevention of bullying, harassment, and hate speech in education and training has been addressed through various means, including inter-sectoral cooperation and addressing these issues in nonformal learning contexts.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What is the current status of young people not in employment, education, or training (NEETs)?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Despite a decrease in recent years, over 10% of the youth age cohort remains as NEETs.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How is education and research being utilized to address societal diversification and the trend towards polarization, as well as combat climate change?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: To prevent the polarization trend in society, attention is being paid to the diversification of society through education and research. In this regard, initiatives such as the 'Climate Responsibility in Education' program launched in 2019 are being implemented to strengthen the means of supporting learning about climate responsibility. Furthermore, several higher education institutions are participating in the SDG ranking, which measures their success in delivering on sustainable development goals, including those related to climate change.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps are being taken in education, training, and research to address societal diversification and combat climate change?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Efforts to address societal diversification and combat climate change are being made through education, training, and research. For instance, an awareness-raising programme called 'Climate Responsibility in Education' was launched in 2019 to strengthen the means of supporting climate-related learning. Additionally, several higher education institutions are participating in the SDG ranking to deliver on sustainable development goals, including those related to climate change.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has Finland incorporated the 2030 Agenda into its development policy, and what are the priority areas in this regard?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has integrated the 2030 Agenda into its development policy through several steps since 2016. The country's development policy prioritizes four areas: 1) Women and Girls; 2) Human Dignity and Equality; 3) Education, Research, Art and Culture; and 4) Peace, Security and Stability. These priority areas are defined based on their contribution to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Additionally, Finnish Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) focus on global education related to climate change and enhancing civil society's influence. This education is part of Finland's efforts to implement the 2030 Agenda in its development, foreign, and trade policies. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:85.6.10)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What will Finland be doing regarding the presentation of comprehensive results reports on its development cooperation to the United Nations (UN) and when is the second report due?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland presented its first comprehensive results report on its development cooperation and policy to the UN in 2018. The second comprehensive results report is scheduled to be presented in 2022. New monitoring tools have been implemented to provide clearer evidence of how Finland's development cooperation contributes to the 2030 Agenda.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Why is Finland presenting comprehensive results reports on its development cooperation to the UN and what are the new monitoring tools used for?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland presents comprehensive results reports on its development cooperation to the UN to demonstrate its contributions towards addressing the most serious development challenges in its priority areas. New monitoring tools have been implemented to track the implementation of these efforts and show more clearly how Finland's development cooperation supports the 2030 Agenda.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has Finland incorporated the 2030 Agenda and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into its development policies and programs?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has integrated the 2030 Agenda and SDGs into its guidelines for civil society in development policy (2017), funding instruments for civil society, including application criteria and reporting requirements. Finland also played a significant role in promoting international policy discussions on integrating the 2030 Agenda into results-based management of development cooperation, as evidenced by the adoption of the Finnish National Indicators for Agenda 2030 in 2019. Additionally, the 2030 Agenda and SDGs are included in Finland's national budget framework (2017).

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What steps has Finland taken to promote the integration of the 2030 Agenda into international policy discussions and development cooperation practices?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has been an active promoter of international policy discussions on integrating the 2030 Agenda into results-based management of development cooperation. A notable achievement was the adoption of Finnish National Indicators for Agenda 2030 in 2019. Finland has also integrated the 2030 Agenda into its guidelines for civil society in development policy (2017) and its funding instruments for civil society, including application criteria and reporting requirements. The 2030 Agenda and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are also included in Finland's national budget framework (2017).

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role does Finland play in promoting the 2030 Agenda in the EU's future financing of external relations, specifically in relation to the negotiations for the new Partnership between the EU and the African, Caribbean, and Pacific countries?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has been actively promoting the 2030 Agenda as the overall framework in the EU's future financing of external relations. In the ongoing negotiations, Finland has specifically focused on mainstreaming Sustainable Development Goals 5 (Gender equality) and 13 (Climate action) in the regulation establishing the new partnership between the EU and the African, Caribbean, and Pacific countries. This means that these goals will be prioritized and integrated into the policies and funding decisions made under this new partnership. By advocating for the inclusion of these goals, Finland aims to contribute to sustainable and equitable development in partner countries while addressing some of the most pressing global challenges. Additionally, the promotion of gender equality and climate action aligns with Finland's own national priorities and international commitments.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland approach the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in its financing period from 2021 to 2027?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland emphasizes mainstreaming the SDGs when programming its next financial period (2021-2027). This commitment is rooted in Finland's value base, which prioritizes human rights, the rule of law, democracy, peace, freedom, and equality in all international activities. Finland's foreign and security policy also relies on good bilateral relationships, an active role within international organizations, and effective multilateral cooperation and promotion of a rules-based international system. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8, 2020 Finland - Report on the Implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What values underpin Finland's foreign and security policy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland's foreign and security policy is grounded in values such as human rights, the rule of law, democracy, peace, freedom, and equality. These principles guide Finland's international activities and are essential to maintaining good bilateral relationships, an active role within international organizations, and effective multilateral cooperation and promotion of a rules-based international system. (Source: Publications of the Prime Minister's Office 2020:8, 2020 Finland - Report on the Implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development)

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role does Finland play in strengthening the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) and promoting international human rights, focusing on specific groups such as women, indigenous peoples, and persons with disabilities?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland works actively towards strengthening the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) and its effectiveness in implementing the 2030 Agenda, ensuring adherence to international law, democracy, and human rights. Finland supports the functioning and independence of the Commissioner for Human Rights and other human rights monitoring mechanisms, and contributes to their resources. Key thematic priorities of Finland's international human rights policy include the rights of women and girls, indigenous peoples, and persons with disabilities. Finland's efforts aim to promote and protect these groups' human rights both domestically and internationally. Additionally, Finland ensures that all actions align with international law and respect for human rights.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland contribute to the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) and promote various human rights, specifically focusing on women, indigenous peoples, and persons with disabilities?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland plays an active role in strengthening the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) and its capacity to implement the 2030 Agenda, upholding international law, democracy, and human rights. Finland supports the Commissioner for Human Rights and other human rights monitoring mechanisms, contributing to their resources. Finland prioritizes the rights of women and girls, indigenous peoples, and persons with disabilities within its international human rights policy. Through this commitment, Finland aims to ensure the protection and promotion of these groups' human rights both at home and abroad, always adhering to international law and respecting human rights principles.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: In what ways did Finland promote human rights during its EU presidency in 2019?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: During Finland's EU presidency in 2019, it actively promoted the mainstreaming of human rights defenders, women and girls' rights in various sectors of the UN's foreign and security policy.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role does Finland play in international crisis management and how does it align with its foreign and security policy objectives?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland actively participates in international crisis management as a means to promote peace and stability, which aligns with its foreign and security policy priorities and objectives, including those related to the 2030 Agenda. The President of Finland has also taken initiatives to increase the effectiveness of institutions and promote the rule of law, as well as human rights-centered artificial intelligence. Finland's contributions to international crisis management are based on its national priorities.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How have Finland's initiatives as President of (2019) affected the institution's effectiveness and promotion of the rule of law?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: During his presidency in 2019, Finland took initiatives to increase the institution's effectiveness and promote the rule of law, demonstrating a commitment to these values both domestically and internationally. These efforts reflect Finland's strong focus on upholding the rule of law and promoting human rights, particularly in the context of human rights-centered artificial intelligence.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland contribute to international crisis management, and what principles does it prioritize?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland promotes democracy, good governance, and human rights during international crisis management. It focuses on protecting civilians, preventing sexual violence in conflicts, and upholding the rights of women and children. Additionally, Finland takes a comprehensive approach to crisis management by enhancing security and stability and strengthening the capabilities and capacity of conflict-driven countries. Mitigating climate change is also an overarching principle that Finland incorporates into all its policies and activities. Therefore, Finland's involvement in international crisis management aims to promote peace, stability, and respect for human rights while addressing the challenges of climate change.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are some specific ways Finland contributes to international crisis management?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland contributes to international crisis management by promoting democracy, good governance, and human rights. Specifically, it focuses on protecting civilians, preventing sexual violence in conflicts, and upholding the rights of women and children. In addition, Finland takes a comprehensive approach to crisis management by enhancing security and stability and strengthening the capabilities and capacity of conflict-driven countries. Furthermore, Finland prioritizes mitigating climate change as an overarching principle in all its policies and activities related to crisis management. Thus, Finland's involvement in international crisis management addresses both immediate security concerns and long-term global challenges.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role does Finland play in promoting women and youth participation in peace processes and implementing the Women, Peace and Security agenda?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland prioritizes the inclusion of women and youth in peace processes and crisis management activities as part of its commitment to the Women, Peace and Security agenda. The country has developed a third National Action Plan (2018-2021) to ensure women's meaningful participation and mainstream gender perspectives in all sectors. Finland also plans to prepare the world's first National Action Plan on the implementation of Resolution 1325 (2000) on Women, Peace and Security. Additionally, Finland supports the 2030 Agenda and emphasizes the importance of arms control in promoting peace, security, and sustainable development, particularly through the achievement of target 16.4. The involvement of civil society is considered essential throughout these efforts. Finland's actions contribute to the realization of the 2030 Agenda and the promotion of peace and security worldwide.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does Finland support disarmament efforts and integrate the 2030 Agenda into its trade policy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland supports disarmament efforts through humanitarian mine action, control of illicit small arms and light weapons, and regulating the international arms trade. In regards to the 2030 Agenda, Finland has integrated its objectives into its and EU trade policy. The EU recognizes international trade as a driver for inclusive economic growth and poverty reduction, contributing to sustainable development. Finland, as an EU member, exercises its trade policy through this union.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role does Finland play in supporting disarmament efforts and how does it incorporate the 2030 Agenda into its trade policy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland supports disarmament efforts through initiatives such as humanitarian mine action, controlling illicit small arms and light weapons, and regulating the international arms trade. Additionally, Finland has integrated the objectives of the 2030 Agenda into its trade policy as a member of the EU. The EU acknowledges international trade as a catalyst for economic growth, poverty reduction, and sustainable development. Consequently, Finland exercises its trade policy through the EU framework.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role does the WTO play in Finland's trade policy, and how has Finland supported the organization's initiatives towards least developed countries?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The WTO plays a significant role in Finland's trade policy by promoting a universal, rules-based, open, transparent, predictable, inclusive, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system. Finland fully supports this objective and has been an advocate for meaningful trade liberalization. Additionally, the WTO has provided duty-free and quota-free market access to imports from least developed countries (LDCs) for several years. Finland has been a supporter of this provision, contributing to targets 10.A.1 and 17.12.1. specifically. This means that Finland allows LDCs to export their goods to Finland without any tariffs or quotas. This initiative aims to help these countries develop economically and reduce poverty. Overall, Finland's trade policy aligns closely with the goals and principles of the WTO.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How has Finland contributed to increasing exports for developing countries, particularly LDCs, and what initiatives has it taken regarding fisheries subsidies?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has been an advocate for increasing exports from developing countries, especially LDCs, and has faced the challenge of their limited trade capacity rather than lack of market access. To address this issue, Finland has supported the International Aid for Trade initiative since 2005, which provides trade-related development assistance. In addition, Finland has actively participated in negotiations on fisheries subsidies reform under the auspices of the European Union and has backed the efforts to curb illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing as part of this collective action. Furthermore, according to the PATH2030 evaluation, Finland offers excellent opportunities for promoting sustainable development work across all administrative branches within its foreign policy.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role has Finland played in supporting developing countries' export growth and addressing fisheries subsidies issues?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: Finland has been instrumental in advocating for increased exports from developing countries, specifically LDCs, recognizing the challenge of their limited trade capacity instead of market access. Since 2005, Finland has been a strong supporter of the International Aid for Trade initiative, which aims to provide trade-related development assistance to these nations. In terms of fisheries subsidies, Finland has actively engaged in negotiations on fisheries subsidies reform as part of the European Union and has advocated for measures to combat illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing. Moreover, the PATH2030 evaluation highlights Finland's potential to foster sustainable development collaborations across all governmental departments in its foreign policy.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Why is there a call for increasing development cooperation appropriations to 0.7 percent of GNP in Finland's implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the promotion of a human rights-based approach in Finland's foreign policy require significant resources. An evaluation has emphasized the importance of having a credible plan and broad-based commitment to increase development cooperation appropriations to reach this target. This would enable Finland to effectively contribute to sustainable development efforts on a global scale. However, achieving this goal will take considerable effort and resources. Therefore, the call for increasing development cooperation appropriations to 0.7 percent of GNP is essential for Finland's successful implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What are the key challenges in implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and promoting a human rights-based approach through Finland's foreign policy?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the promotion of a human rights-based approach through Finland's foreign policy necessitate a great deal of work and resources. An evaluation has highlighted the need for a credible plan and broad-based commitment to increase development cooperation appropriations to 0.7 percent of GNP. Despite these challenges, Finland continues to strive towards making progress in these areas.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: How does the Finnish model support the UN and its agencies, particularly in regards to implementing the 2030 Agenda?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Finnish model provides strong support for a rules-based system, which translates into significant backing for organizations and high-profile work within the United Nations. Governments, including Finland, not only bear the responsibility for implementing the 2030 Agenda at the national level but can also assume roles in promoting and supporting the international implementation of the agenda. This dual commitment ensures effective progress towards the sustainable development goals set out in the 2030 Agenda.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: In what ways can governments contribute to the global implementation of the 2030 Agenda beyond their national commitments?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: In addition to their national responsibilities, governments can play an active role in promoting and supporting the international implementation of the 2030 Agenda. They can do this by taking on leadership positions within the United Nations and other relevant organizations, providing financial and technical assistance to countries requiring help, and fostering collaboration between nations to address common challenges related to the SDGs.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: Why did the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC) propose declaring the year 2020 as the International Year of Plant Health (IYPH 2020)?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The FAO and IPPC proposed declaring the year 2020 as IYPH 2020 because healthy plants form the basis for all life on Earth, support ecosystem functions and food security, protect the environment, forests, and biodiversity from plant pests, address the effects of climate change, and contribute to ending hunger, malnutrition, and poverty while boosting economic development. Additionally, plant health is crucial for safeguarding human health and ensuring sustainable agriculture. The initiative aims to raise global awareness about the importance of plant health and the actions required to maintain it. The proposal was launched at the 13th Regular Session of the Commission on Phytosanitary Measures in 2015.

no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..question: What role did the Finnish government play in promoting plant health management as part of the International Year of Plant Health (IYPH) 2020, and what organizations supported this initiative?
no_26265VNR_Report_Finland_2020_removed..answer: The Finnish government took the lead in raising awareness and facilitating actions towards plant health management during the International Year of Plant Health (IYPH) 2020. This initiative was endorsed by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2016 and 2017, respectively. The Government of Finland, along with 94 cosponsors, proposed a resolution on this matter, which was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in December 2018. More information about Finland's sustainable development policy related to this work can be found in the evaluation report available at this link: path2030-an-evaluation-of-finlands-sustainable-development-policy/.
